The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An overview of the many socialist and socialist inspired political movements, parties and governments which formed after the end of the colonial era in Africa.
This is a good introduction to socialist ideologies and regimes in 20th century Africa.
I learned a lot about socialism, post-colonial Africa, and how alternative systems and futures were developed.
I learned a lot about socialist experiments, movements, and ideology in Africa throughout the 20th century.

I acquired an in-depth understanding of communism, socialism, African socialism, Afromarxism, and scientific socialism, and learned about some of the great socialist leaders of Africa. I also improved my research and writing skills.

Understanding the history of socialism and African socialism in the context of post-colonial Africa. Topics covered included African socialism v Traditional African communalism, economics of African socialism, social engineering and gender in socialist Africa, negritude and pan-africanism, Afromarxism, national culture and socialism, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covers extremely interesting history and the readings are very engaging if you are interested in the history of Africa and/or socialism. However the discussions are very hands-off of Professor Machava's part, which means that sometimes it can be hard to have meaningful exchanges or to know what to make of the readings and themes of the class.

Strengths - Readings, Overall Structures, Professor 
Weaknesses - Format felt repetitive at times
It was a very strong course with lots of interesting information.

This class's strengths would have to be the structure of the syllabus and caliber of class discussions, both of which were exceptional. The reading material each week was varied and exposed students to a diverse range of topics while also remaining coherent with the overall themes of the class. Discussions were consistently deep, thoughtful, and respectful even when there was disagreement. The one area of improvement I would suggest is to potentially eliminate the final paper rough draft requirement which I felt came a bit too early on in the semester even after being extended for students to produce quality work. Perhaps replacing it with a requirement for a first 5-10 pages or a more comprehensive prospectus might have the same effect of requiring students to think about their topics in advance without creating too much of a time crunch so far out from the actual deadline.

I enjoyed the open discussions led by students. I only wish that Professor Machava led more PowerPoint presentations because they were quite informational. I also wish we had started earlier on the final writing assignment.

Discussions were great and Prof Machava was able to facilitate them in an engaging way; I wish we had more benchmarks and check-ins for the final paper throughout the semester and also feedback on the reviews!!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Nothing in particular needs improvement.
Professor Machava did a good job making the class engaging and interactive over zoom, especially with student presentations/leading discussion/weekly reading reviews.

I think having students share their weekly reviews and lead discussions kept participants engaged. Maybe more different interactive activities could be incorporated to increase engagement (for example, more breakout rooms to get to know the other students in the class, discuss ideas, and then share out to the larger group).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in socialism, decolonization and/or African history this is the course for you.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone interested 20th century Africa or socialism.
Yes

Absolutely, this class is well structured and explores a subject which has so many different rabbit holes to go down no matter where your interests may lie. Discussions are run well and the professor provides great feedback and support, overall a really phenomenal course I would recommend to anybody.

Yes! From the title of the course I was drawn into what it had to offer. The course material and its organization helped to create a solid foundation in my understanding of socialism in a broad context and also in more country-specific circumstances (Ghana, Tanzania, Senegal, etc.). I talked about this course so much that I even got a friend interested to join a Zoom class. Just be mindful that there are a lot of assigned weekly readings.

Yes! If you are at all interested in understanding the factors that led Africans to experiment with socialism after the fall of colonial and imperial powers + want to understand the history/development of African socialism, this is a great class that introduces you to important African socialist thinkers.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom seminar.
